content: The legacy of the painter Bob Thompson, who died at 28 in 1966, is well out of proportion to his short life. A retrospective now at the Colby College Museum of Art in Waterville, Maine, through Jan. 9, presents a stunning look at a Black painter who looked to the old masters for inspiration; his bold attitude toward art history is summed up in the show’s title, “This House Is Mine.”

title: The Secret Toll of Racial Ambiguity
description: Rebecca Hall’s new film adaptation of the 1929 novel “Passing” has cracked open a public conversation about colorism and privilege.
content: When Rebecca Hall read Nella Larsen’s groundbreaking 1929 novel, “Passing,” over a decade ago, she felt an intense, immediate attachment to it. The story seemed to clarify so much that was mysterious about her own identity — the unnameable gaps in her family history that shaped her life in their very absence, the way a sinkhole in the road distorts the path of traffic blocks away.

content: Fifty floors above street level, in her temporary Manhattan apartment with its panoramic views, the West End theater star Sharon D Clarke was missing her wife.

title: S&P 500 falls just short of a record as investors balance inflation concerns with strong earnings.
description: A new high for the S&P 500 would cap a volatile stretch of trading that saw the benchmark fall nearly 5 percent in September.
content: The S&P 500 posted its sixth-consecutive gain on Wednesday but fell short of a record after a Federal Reserve official expressed concerns about inflation, suggesting that policymakers were prepared to pull back on support for the economy if price gains continue to hold up.

content: Tesla made $1.6 billion in the three months ending in September, the second quarter in a row that its profit has exceeded the billion-dollar mark.

title: Earl Old Person, Chief of the Blackfeet Nation, Dies at 92
description: As the longest-serving elected tribal leader in the country, he pushed for self-sufficiency and greater respect from the federal government.
content: Earl Old Person, the chief of the Blackfeet Nation who for nearly 70 years pushed for its economic development and self-sufficiency and against what he saw as an unreliable, at times untrustworthy federal government, died on Oct. 13 in Browning, Mont. He was 92.

title: Transgender Woman Flees Malaysia After Prison Threat for Wearing Hijab
description: The Islamic authorities want to imprison her for wearing female clothing at a religious event and threatened to put her in a rehabilitation camp where she could “return to the right path.”
content: In February 2018, on her birthday, Nur Sajat put on a demure hijab and attended a Muslim prayer session at a new building she was inaugurating near the Malaysian capital, Kuala Lumpur. Three years after that sartorial choice, the Malaysian authorities have charged her with “insulting Islam” and wearing female attire.

title: An Unassuming Prince Dons the Velvet Cloak at Ballet Theater

content: Standing in a corner of a rehearsal studio at American Ballet Theater, the dancer Thomas Forster cuts a striking figure. He’s tall, but at 35, still boyish. With his head slightly bowed, he has the air of a melancholy prince in a fairy-tale illustration, though he’s wearing a surgical mask and athletic shorts under a dark velvet cloak.

title: Democrats Back Away From Raising Tax Rates to Pay for Agenda
description: Responding to concerns from a key centrist, Senator Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona, the White House and leading Democrats are instead discussing a range of other taxes to pay for the plan.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration and congressional Democrats are moving toward dropping their push to raise corporate and individual income tax rates to pay for their sprawling domestic policy bill, instead drafting a plan that includes new ways to tax the wealthy and multinational corporations, according to people familiar with the discussions.

author: By Molly Creeden
title: The Creator of ‘Salad for President’ Celebrates Her New Book
description: Julia Sherman looks back at a recent gathering at which she previewed recipes from ‘Arty Parties’ for friends — and shares tips on throwing a communal dinner of your own.
content: Julia Sherman is famous for salad. In 2017, after her blog of the same name had grown a healthy following, she published the cookbook “Salad for President.” Both presented salad recipes that Sherman, who received her undergraduate degree from the Rhode Island School of Design and has an M.F.A. from Columbia, often developed in collaboration with artists: wild-seeded greens and edible flowers with Madeleine Fitzpatrick, shredded brussels sprouts and shaved apple with Tauba Auerbach. Artists, it turned out, have a knack for combining ingredients to colorful and delicious effect, and salad making could be, if not always a central part of one’s practice — in 2014, Sherman asked the artist Alison Knowles to restage her 1962 performance piece “Make a Salad” on the roof of MoMA PS1 in Queens — then at least a way of bringing people together.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sheriff Is Charged With Falsely Accusing Black Newspaper Carrier of Threats
description: Ed Troyer, the sheriff of Pierce County in Washington State, was charged with making a false claim after saying the man had threatened to kill him, prosecutors said.
content: A sitting sheriff in Washington State has been charged with making a false claim that a Black man had driven up to his home and threatened to kill him, prosecutors said.

title: Gates Foundation Pledges $120 Million to Help Get Covid Pills Quickly to Poor Countries
description: Regulatory hurdles and supply chain issues could slow efforts to produce generic versions of Merck’s antiviral molnupiravir for developing nations, despite licensing agreements.
content: The first easy-to-use Covid-19 treatment could be available in the United States by the end of this year, but it is unlikely to reach developing countries, where hundreds of millions of people remain without access to vaccines, until at least the middle of 2022, according to public health officials.

author: By Peter Coy
title: Colombians Are Uniting Around Land Reform. Here’s Why.
description: Helping farmers is an idea that unites the country's left and right.
content: During Secretary of State Antony Blinken’s visit to Colombia this week, the issue of land reform will be high on the agenda. Farmers’ lack of title to their land in much of rural Colombia is an important if invisible contributor to two of the country’s biggest problems: illegal cultivation of coca, the source of cocaine, and the enduring strength of guerrilla movements, including the remains of FARC, the deadly Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia. The government promised “comprehensive rural reform” in the first chapter of its final peace accord with FARC in 2016 — but there’s a way to go before it can claim to have made good on that promise.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Chameleon Street’: The Art of the Con

content: Praised but marginalized, a Sundance winner and a commercial flop, Wendell B. Harris Jr.’s “Chameleon Street” is unique, not just because it was the first and so far the only 35-millimeter film Harris has written and made. This 1990 independent feature — funded by his parents and a group of Flint, Mich., businessmen — is also a hall of mirrors that does not exclude the viewer’s reflection.

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Between The Rock and a Hard Place
description: Peter Thiel, decency and the supposed “pro-wrestlization” of tweeting.
content: When I was a young girl, my grandfather took me to a lot of pro-wrestling matches. He was a major aficionado of the “sport” and was also an amateur promoter of events, so he knew everyone in the early days. That meant I was lucky enough to meet wrestlers like the over-seven-foot “eighth wonder of world,” André the Giant. This French performer was an overwhelming presence to me, a kid who was topping out at three-foot-nothing. But he was unusually sweet and generous every time I saw him, as he was to all of his fans. Most of the characters in the business were like this off the mat, too, despite their faux beefs and overwrought dramas while they were on it. Thus, I always had good feelings about pro wrestling right through to The Rock.

description: A study in mice raises intriguing questions about the ways that hormones influence the brain and motivate the body to move.
content: Estrogen may change brain activity in ways that could affect how physically active we are, according to a remarkable new study in mice that looked at DNA, hormones and brain cells. title: Capturing the Magic of Movies
description: The long-awaited Academy Museum of Motion Pictures recognizes many of those who worked behind the scenes and comes to terms with Hollywood’s past.
content: This article is part of our latest Fine Arts & Exhibits special report, about how art institutions are helping audiences discover new options for the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Why Kids May Be Melting Down at School
description: Teachers across the country on how to support children’s social and emotional learning.
content: I have heard from many readers and friends that their kids are struggling to adjust to in-person schooling this year. For the little ones, there’s more separation anxiety, which means more tears at drop-off, and struggles to even get out the door. For older children and teens, I’m hearing that some previously motivated kids are less engaged. Perhaps they fell behind during remote learning and feel discouraged now that they’re back in the classroom. Others have anxiety about the virus and may still be reeling from grief if they’ve lost family members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Ancient-DNA Researchers Set Ethics Guidelines for Their Work
description: New, international standards for handling ancient genetic material draw support from many scientists, criticism from others.
content: In 2017, a team of scientists successfully extracted the DNA of members of a Pueblo community who were buried starting around 1,300 years ago in what is now Chaco Canyon in New Mexico. The DNA suggested that these people had lived in a matrilineal society, with power passed down through generations of mothers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Without Kyrie Irving, Nets Struggle Against the Bucks
description: Coach Steve Nash and the team’s other stars, Kevin Durant and James Harden, have had to re-envision a plan on the fly.
content: It was difficult to ignore the Kyrie Irving-size elephant not in the room as the Nets opened the season by getting pummeled, 127-104, by the Milwaukee Bucks on Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Mark Zuckerberg will be added to a Facebook privacy lawsuit.
description: The District of Columbia case, which grew out of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, could expose the chief executive to financial and other penalties.
content: WASHINGTON — The attorney general for the District of Columbia on Wednesday added Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, to a consumer protection lawsuit, in one of the first efforts by a regulator to expose him personally to potential financial and other penalties. The attorney general, Karl Racine, said that continuing interviews and reviews of internal documents for the case had revealed that Mr. Zuckerberg played a much more active role in key decisions than prosecutors had known.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Mr. October Traded His Pinstripes for an Astros Cap
description: Reggie Jackson, the Hall of Fame slugger and longtime Yankees adviser, has a new role with the Astros, helping reassure the team as postseason pressure mounts.
content: BOSTON — It was brisk and windy during batting practice Monday, and the skies were black over old Fenway Park. Reggie Jackson smiled. “October weather,” he said, as nobody else on the planet quite could.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: The Webb Telescope’s Latest Stumbling Block: Its Name
description: The long-awaited successor to the Hubble Space Telescope is scheduled to launch in December. But the NASA official for whom it is named has been accused of homophobia.
content: Many astronomers were disappointed when NASA’s up-and-coming space telescope, the successor to the vaunted Hubble Space Telescope, was named for James Webb, a former NASA administrator who led the agency through the glory years of the Apollo missions. Why not name it for an astronomer, the way other space missions — Hubble, Kepler — have been, instead of a bean counter? But they held their tongues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: A Show With Its Host City, New Orleans, as the Protagonist
description: The contemporary art triennial Prospect New Orleans looks at the city’s cyclical history of challenges.
content: This article is part of our latest Fine Arts & Exhibits special report, about how art institutions are helping audiences discover new options for the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Plan Filed to Scrap Race as Factor in N.F.L. Concussion Settlement
description: The revised agreement eliminates race as a consideration in evaluating dementia claims by former players.
content: After months of haggling, the N.F.L. and lawyers representing Black players who accused the league of discrimination filed a joint proposal that will scrap the use of a race-based method to evaluate dementia claims made by former players in the league’s concussion settlement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: So It Goes
description: David W. Tuffs forces solvers to make some hard choices.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Hello and happy Wednesday! Today’s puzzle takes us halfway to Friday with a rollicking good time built around one of my favorite kinds of wordplay. A hearty thank-you to its constructor, David W. Tuffs, for making this delightfully weird puzzle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisy Alioto
title: The Strange Appeal of Shelter TikTok
description: TikTok has developed its own approach to home-design content: Skip over the home to obsess over the objects inside.
content: The apartment appears in flashes as a song by Frank Ocean plays. We see a white couch with throw pillows: white squares, pink square, ocher orb, black square. Later come quick cuts: to a standing bookshelf (white spines only), to the throw pillows again, to a transparent coffee table (an opportunity, really, to show off the checked rug beneath). We see a pet dog on bedspread, a side table, a TV stand, the couch again, a dining area with Thonet-style chairs. Among these curated images is a shelf of curated objects, centered on a Polaroid camera. Then come the bedroom, the bar cart, the white Smeg toaster. It all goes by before we can absorb it, but we aren’t meant to absorb it — only to have impressions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Do You Think Your Favorite Book or Movie Character Eats For Dinner?
description: A bevy of new cookbooks explores the culinary preferences of beloved fictional characters. Whose meal plans would you most like to know?
content: Eleven from “Stranger Things” loves Eggo waffles. The Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles live on pizza. Harry Potter routinely chugs Butterbeer. What do you think your favorite characters eat? What does Katniss Everdeen in “Hunger Games” eat when she’s hungry or the Incredible Hulk when he is hangry? Does Baby Yoda eat baby food?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Brooklyn Lawyers Plead Guilty in Firebomb Case
description: Colinford Mattis and Urooj Rahman expressed regret for the attack on a police car in May 2020. Each could face 10 years in prison.
content: On a May night in 2020, two young lawyers — high achievers who had risen from working-class roots to prestigious schools and promising careers — joined thousands of others on the streets of Brooklyn to protest the murder of George Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: China’s Bullying Is Becoming a Danger to the World and Itself
description: Does Xi understand the cost of the distrust he’s fostering at home and abroad?
content: Ever since Deng Xiaoping opened China to the world in the late 1970s, many in the West wanted to see the country succeed, because we thought China — despite its brutal authoritarian political structure — was on a path to a more open economy and society. Alas, President Xi Jinping has reversed steps in that direction in ways that could pose a real danger to China’s future development and a real danger to the rest of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Queen ‘Reluctantly’ Cancels Trip, Citing Medical Advice
description: Britain’s 95-year-old monarch will not travel to Northern Ireland but is “in good spirits,” Buckingham Palace said.
content: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II, who has been a redoubtable presence in British public life since the death of her husband, Prince Philip, in April, canceled a trip to Northern Ireland on Wednesday because doctors advised her to rest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Powell
title: M.I.T.’s Choice of Lecturer Ignited Criticism. So Did Its Decision to Cancel.
description: Dorian Abbot is a scientist who has opposed aspects of affirmative action. He is now at the center of an argument over free speech and acceptable discourse.
content: CHICAGO — The Massachusetts Institute of Technology invited the geophysicist Dorian Abbot to give a prestigious public lecture this autumn. He seemed a natural choice, a scientific star who studies climate change and whether planets in distant solar systems might harbor atmospheres conducive to life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: House Democratic Retirements Pile Up as Party Fears Losing Majority
description: As they survey a grim political landscape for their party, three senior House Democrats opt for retirement and lament the factionalism within their ranks.
content: WASHINGTON — The quickening pace of Democratic retirements in the House may be the clearest indication yet that the party’s hopes of maintaining its narrow majority are fading amid President Biden’s sagging approval ratings, ongoing legislative struggles and the prospect of redrawn congressional districts that will put some seats out of reach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Night Teeth’ Review: You’re So Vein
description: In this spiritless Netflix movie, an unwitting chauffeur in Los Angeles is drawn into a murderous vampire plot.
content: The undead are the coolest kids in town in Adam Randall’s “Night Teeth,” a strangely listless vampire tale that unspools with some style and precious little sense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran, turning more to imports, plans to abandon one of its homegrown Covid vaccines.
description: The defense ministry said there was too little demand for its Fakhravac vaccine to justify producing it, and blamed the health ministry for reneging on promised orders.
content: Iran plans to abandon production of its Fakhravac Covid-19 vaccine for lack of demand, its defense ministry said on Tuesday. Iran’s five other domestic Covid vaccines could also be in jeopardy, as Iranians have shown they prefer imported vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Dozens Drown in India and Nepal as Monsoon Season Fails to End
description: The death toll continued to rise on Wednesday as landslides and flooding damaged homes and stranded thousands of people.
content: NEW DELHI — Unseasonably heavy rainfall has destroyed crops, washed away bridges and killed dozens of people across India and Nepal in a reminder of the devastation caused by a changing climate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: The Knicks Are Ready for a Sequel. The Good Kind.
description: The Knicks are positioned to build on last season’s success after an off-season of smart moves.
content: What is this feeling, so sudden and new?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: The Horse You Rode In On May Have Been Made in Southern Russia
description: A comprehensive new paper tested 273 ancient horse genomes to pinpoint when and where modern horses were domesticated.
content: For thousands of years, the grassy plains of Europe and Asia were home to a mosaic of genetically distinct horse lineages. But a single lineage galloped ahead to overtake and replace all the other wild horses. This domesticated lineage became the horse of our modern imagination: slender legs, a muscular back and a mane that shimmers in the wind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: ‘Promises Made Just Have to Be Promises Kept’: Black Colleges Feel Stung by Democrats
description: A rift is forming over a plan to provide only $2 billion out of the $20 billion President Biden proposed to help level the playing field in his social spending package.
content: WASHINGTON — As part of President Biden’s sprawling domestic policy agenda, he proposed tens of billions of dollars for historically Black colleges and universities as a long-overdue down payment on leveling the playing field between them and their wealthier, predominantly white-serving counterparts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Kroeber
title: Evergrande Isn’t China’s Only Economic Worry
description: Getting the economy back on track for the long haul requires making aggressive reforms now.
content: Crushed by $300 billion in debt, Evergrande, one of China’s biggest property developers, is sliding toward bankruptcy. This has prompted fears of a wider property crash or even a financial crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex V. Cipolle
title: In Minneapolis, a Thriving Center for Indigenous Art
description: The eight-block American Indian Cultural Corridor celebrates Native American art and commerce.
content: This article is part of our latest Fine Arts & Exhibits special report, about how art institutions are helping audiences discover new options for the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: Vikings Were in the Americas Exactly 1,000 Years Ago
description: By studying tree rings and using a dash of astrophysics, researchers have pinned down a precise year that settlers from Europe were on land that would come to be known as Newfoundland.
content: Six decades ago, a husband-and-wife team of archaeologists discovered the remains of a settlement on the windswept northern tip of Newfoundland. The site’s eight timber-framed structures resemble Viking buildings in Greenland, and archaeological artifacts found there — including a bronze cloak pin — are decidedly Norse in style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Found’ Review: Three Adoptees Seek Their China Roots
description: This documentary, taking emotional cues from the teenagers at its center, is smart, illuminating and tender.
content: A nanny at an orphanage in China’s Guangdong Province speaks of the infants she cared for over the years. “My heart ached whenever I sent a baby away … What was to become of them?” Amanda Lipitz’s adoption documentary “Found,” rife with poignant moments, provides not one simple answer to that plaintive question but three beautifully complex ones — in the cousins Chloe, Sadie and Lily, who travel to China from Arizona, Tennessee and Oklahoma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: The True Cost of Upgrading Your Phone
description: Buying a $1,000 iPhone can be equivalent to giving up $17,000 in retirement savings or 2,500 cups of coffee.
content: Let’s talk about buying an iPhone for $1,000. Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive, once compared this eye-popping price tag to buying a cup of coffee a day over a year. No big deal, right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Meet the Lineup for the DealBook Online Summit
description: Tim Cook, Mary Barra and Matthew McConaughey are among the headliners.
content: The DealBook Online Summit is coming up on Nov. 9 and 10. The two-day event, celebrating the 20th anniversary of DealBook, will bring together some of the most influential people in business and policy. It’s free to watch from anywhere in the world if you register here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bob Morris
title: The Return of the Shadowman
description: A stealth artist from Seattle has been replicating the ’80s street art of Richard Hambleton throughout Manhattan. Is this a tribute, a marketing tool — or both?
content: He committed his first crime shortly after 2:00 in the morning on a recent Friday. With an athlete’s grace, he hopped a rusty gate and pulled a plastic bottle of black latex paint from his backpack. Then, in broad muscular strokes, he painted a shadowy silhouette of a scraggly man on the glass door beneath an abandoned cafe on West 23rd Street. It took form in 10 minutes, finished when he splattered droplets creating the impression that the brains of the menacing figure’s head were exploding as if from a geyser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman and Eshe Nelson
title: Boris Johnson Claims a Positive in Britain’s Shortages. Economists Disagree.
description: Wages in some industries are rising because employers can’t find enough workers. That’s not a path to long-term growth, analysts say.
content: In a country bedeviled by acute shortages of goods and workers, Prime Minister Boris Johnson is portraying the chaos as a source of national revival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Dune’ Review: A Hero in the Making, on Shifting Sands
description: Denis Villeneuve’s adaptation is an equally sweeping and intimate take on Frank Herbert’s future-shock epic.
content: In a galaxy far, far away, a young man in a sea of sand faces a foreboding destiny. The threat of war hangs in the air. At the brink of a crisis, he navigates a feudalistic world with an evil emperor, noble houses and subjugated peoples, a tale right out of mythology and right at home in George Lucas’s brainpan. But this is “Dune,” baby, Frank Herbert’s science-fiction opus, which is making another run at global box-office domination even as it heads toward controversy about what it and its messianic protagonist signify.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Emily Cochrane and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden Backs Compromise to Win a Vast Social Agenda
description: The president’s trip to Scranton, Pa., comes as Democrats close in on a deal to advance two bills carrying a scaled-back version of his domestic policy priorities.
content: WASHINGTON — As he tries to steer his party toward a vast, once-in-a-generation investment in social programs, President Biden is paring back his ambitions for clean energy, access to college and help for families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Madigan, Patricia Mazzei and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Gunman Pleads Guilty in Parkland School Shooting
description: A jury in Florida will recommend whether he should be sentenced to life in prison or death for the rampage that left 17 people dead at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.
content: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — The former student who waged a deadly attack against his classmates and teachers in Parkland, Fla., in 2018 pleaded guilty on Wednesday to the premeditated murder of 17 people and the attempted murder of 17 others, leaving his fate — either spending his life in prison or facing execution — in the hands of a jury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum and Ben Protess
title: Trump Organization, Already Under Indictment, Faces New Criminal Inquiry
description: The investigation, by the Westchester County district attorney’s office, increases the legal scrutiny of the former president and his family business.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s family business, which is already under indictment in Manhattan, is facing a criminal investigation by another prosecutor’s office that has begun to examine financial dealings at a golf course the company owns, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi
title: New virus cases are rising on some Caribbean islands, the W.H.O. says.
description: Many nations and territories in the region have had trouble rolling out vaccination drives and need to ramp up testing, officials said.
content: Bucking the trend in much of the Americas, several Caribbean countries are reporting significant surges in known coronavirus infections, World Health Organization officials warned on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Detention of an Afghan at Guantánamo Bay Is Ruled Unlawful
description: The decision does not assure the release of the prisoner, who was captured in 2007; Uyghurs who won a similar case languished at the prison for years.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge has ruled that the United States has no legal basis for holding an Afghan man at Guantánamo Bay because although he fought on the side of a militia in Afghanistan, he was not part of Al Qaeda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabrielle Hamilton
title: Fried Oysters Are Delicious. They’re Even Better at Home.
description: They’re a seafood-shack favorite, but making them yourself can be an almost fine-dining experience.
content: I don’t have a first oyster memory. It has been crowded out by so many others, vivid and indelible, that followed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Grooming Tips for the Groom
description: Products and services to help a groom look his best on the big day.
content: From tweezing and teeth whitening to radio-frequency fat removal, grooms have more options than ever to ensure they look their best on their wedding day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Robert Chiarito
title: R. Kelly to Face Another Trial in Chicago, Next August
description: The R&B star was convicted last month in Brooklyn of sex trafficking and racketeering charges after decades of sexual abuse allegations.
content: R. Kelly, the R&B superstar who was convicted last month in Brooklyn on federal racketeering and sex trafficking charges, has been scheduled to stand trial again starting on Aug. 1 in Chicago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How to Talk to the World Through Free Translation Apps
description: Open up Google Translate or Apple’s Translate and your mobile device turns into your personal language interpreter.
content: Need to have a conversation in a language you don’t know, make sense of a printed sign or quickly translate a message? With Google and Apple revving their machine-learning engines in their Google Translate and Apple’s Translate apps, there’s a whole new world of communication possibilities right in your pocket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Russia’s ‘non-working’ week.
content: As the Covid death toll and case numbers soar, Russia will shut down for a seven-day non-working period starting on Oct. 30, President Vladimir Putin announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: The Albums That Transport You
description: Take a trip.
content: Welcome. If each day of the workweek corresponds to a gear on a five-speed car, then Monday might be “starting” and Thursday might be “cruising.” Wednesday, meanwhile, would be an in-between gear, a time when you’re driving around town running errands. When weeks drag, I think about getting to Wednesday, past the revving-up portion of the week and (ideally) into the getting-things-done phase. On Wednesdays, you’re actually getting somewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Spanish Court Agrees to Extradite Former Venezuela Spy Chief to U.S.
description: Hugo Carvajal, once a prominent figure in the government of the Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro, faces drug-trafficking charges in the United States.
content: MADRID — Spain’s highest criminal court agreed on Wednesday to extradite Venezuela’s former intelligence chief, Hugo Carvajal, to the United States, where he faces drug trafficking charges, according to a court statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Jury Acquits Protester Accused in Assault on Wisconsin Lawmaker
description: Kerida O’Reilly, 34, had been accused of attacking State Senator Tim Carpenter at a Black Lives Matter protest, prompting others nearby to attack him.
content: A Wisconsin jury on Tuesday found a woman not guilty of charges that she had beaten a state senator who was recording video of protesters at a Black Lives Matter demonstration last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Putin Won’t Go to Glasgow for Climate Conference
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia may make a speech by video at the United Nations summit, which is seen as pivotal in efforts to stem climate change.
content: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will not attend a United Nations climate summit later this month that is seen as pivotal to reducing emissions of planet-warming gasses, but he may deliver a speech by video link, the Kremlin said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Democrats Search for Path on Voting Rights Amid Republican Blockade
description: Backers of the legislation said they were not giving up as they shifted focus to the need to “restore” the Senate.
content: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats crashed once again on Wednesday into the seemingly impenetrable Republican wall blocking new voting rights legislation, leaving them with a simple question: Now what?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘The Women Fighting to Protect Greenland’
description: In this lesson, students will learn how ordinary citizens stood up for their home. Then, students will consider what things they are willing to fight for.
content: This lesson is a part of our new Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times in general. Learn more and tell us what you think here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Bellinger’s Blast Breathes Life Into Dodgers Offense
description: A three-run homer from the struggling outfielder tied the game and a double by Mookie Betts put Los Angeles ahead to stay. With that, Atlanta’s dreams of a sweep faded away.
content: LOS ANGELES — Just when the fading Los Angeles Dodgers were barely visible above the horizon in this National League Championship Series, Cody Bellinger pulled them back into view in the eighth inning of Game 3. Three-run homers have a way of papering over past failures, and the Dodgers’ list of those was growing by the plate appearance.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Biden’s Climate Plan Stymied by 1 Senator
description: Joe Manchin is a crucial vote and is firmly against a clean electricity program that is the muscle behind the president’s plan to battle climate change.
content: The most powerful part of President Biden’s climate agenda — a program to rapidly replace the nation’s coal- and gas-fired power plants with wind, solar and nuclear energy — has been dropped from the budget bill pending in Congress, after Senator Joe Manchin III, the Democrat from coal-rich West Virginia, told the White House that he strongly opposes the program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Crouse and Kirby Ferguson
title: It’s Quitting Season
description: Time to stop being a martyr to grit.
content: It’s been a brutal few years. But we’ve gritted through. We’ve spent time languishing. We’ve had one giant national burnout. And now, finally, we’re quitting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Owner of Maryland’s Runaway Zebras Is Charged With Animal Cruelty
description: Jerry Lee Holly, 76, was charged a month after one of the wayward zebras was found dead in an illegal snare trap in Upper Marlboro, Md.
content: The owner of the three zebras that escaped from a farm in suburban Maryland in August, delighting residents and stealthily evading efforts to corral them, was charged with three counts of animal cruelty on Tuesday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan and Nicole Hong
title: As Borders Reopen, New York Wants Foreign Tourists Back, and Fast
description: The city’s tourism marketing agency is starting a campaign in several countries to attract visitors after the long pandemic lockout.
content: As New York City struggles to revive its economy from the devastation wrought by the pandemic, one key element is still missing: big-spending foreign tourists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: A Strikeout That Wasn’t Lets the Astros Back Into A.L.C.S.
description: With two outs in the ninth, Nathan Eovaldi thought he had a strike three. Laz Diaz disagreed and by the time the dust settled, Houston had scored seven runs, tying the series.
content: BOSTON — It was the kind of expert curveball that can make a pitcher a lot of money. It left Nathan Eovaldi’s fingertips just so, bent through the air and landed in Christian Vázquez’s glove. It crossed home plate perhaps exactly as Eovaldi intended it to, on the outside edge, dotting the upper, far corner of the strike zone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: From Henry Louis Gates Jr., Another Scholarly Megaproject
description: A book series from Penguin will feature leading writers on the legacy of Black figures including W.E.B. Du Bois, John Hope Franklin, Toni Morrison and Stevie Wonder.
content: The career of the literary scholar Henry Louis Gates Jr. has been marked by a series of intellectual megaprojects, from the landmark 30-volume Schomburg Library of Nineteeth-Century Black Women Writers (1988) and the Norton Anthology of African-American Literature (1996), to the five-volume Africana encyclopedia (2000), and three mammoth biographical dictionaries featuring some 10,000 notable figures from Africa and across the African diaspora.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelia Herrera
title: Helado Negro at the End of the World
description: The Ecuadorean American musician’s new album, “Far In,” is filled with celestial lullabies that confront earthly anxieties.
content: The end is weighing heavy on Helado Negro. Some of his unease stems from traditional concerns, like aging (the musician, born Roberto Carlos Lange, turned 41 this year). But some is a consequence of looming global catastrophes: the existential dread of climate change, the seemingly unending nature of the pandemic. “I know the world has always been in some kind of constant conflict and flux,” he said. “But it feels even heavier now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Amherst College Ends Legacy Admissions Favoring Children of Alumni
description: The highly selective college in Massachusetts will be among the first elite schools in the country to abandon the practice, which has been a persistent barrier to increasing student diversity.
content: Amherst College announced on Wednesday that it would no longer give the children of alumni a boost in the admissions process, becoming one of the first highly selective colleges in the country to abandon a practice that has held back efforts to diversify the top echelons of American higher education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Calls to charge Bolsonaro with crimes against humanity.
content: Jair Bolsonaro, the Brazilian president, should face charges of “crimes against humanity” over his mishandling of the pandemic, according to a forthcoming report from a panel of 11 Brazilian senators. It represents the depths of anger against a leader who has refused to take the pandemic seriously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1971: Paris Installs Giant Air Filters to Combat Pollution
description: Two towers, each measuring 16 and a half feet high, were installed in an area in the east of the city in an experiment to tackle contamination.
content: PARIS, Oct. 19 (NYT). — Two mysterious towers were set up today in the grimy Gare de Lyon area of eastern Paris and one schoolboy was overheard asking: “Are they for launching rockets to the moon?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Everdeen Mason
title: New York Times Crossword to Pause Submissions Starting Nov. 22
description: We will reopen crossword submissions on Jan. 3.
content: A note to our puzzle constructors: We will be pausing submissions starting on Nov. 22, 2021. We will reopen on Jan. 3, 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Dudding
title: Booster Shots, Child Vaccines, Meteor Showers: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Take a Walk in the Garden, Before It’s Too Late
description: Go out and look around. Your garden has things to tell you in the fall.
content: For David L. Culp, the walk is a daily practice, not for its exercise value, but in pursuit of insight. The familiar route he has taken most days, over some 30 growing seasons, is around his two-acre garden in Downingtown, Pa., along the paths he created.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Nadia Chaudhri, Scientist With an End-of-Life Mission, Dies at 43
description: She documented her last months with ovarian cancer on Twitter while raising funds to support students from backgrounds that are underrepresented in the sciences.
content: Nadia Chaudhri, a neuroscientist with terminal ovarian cancer who used her final months to raise money for graduate students of diverse backgrounds and to educate the public about her disease through a widely followed social media chronicle, died on Oct. 5 at a hospital in Montreal. She was 43.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The F.D.A. approves more boosters.
content: The F.D.A. announced highly anticipated decisions on vaccines today: The agency authorized boosters of the Moderna and Johnson & Johnson vaccines, and also allowed for the strategy of mixing and matching doses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: San Francisco temporarily closed an In-N-Out Burger for not checking customers’ vaccine status.
description: The popular burger chain said it refused to become “the vaccination police for any government.”
content: An In-N-Out in San Francisco has reopened for takeout after being temporarily shut down on Oct. 14 by the city’s department of health for violating Covid-19 health protocols by not checking patrons for proof of vaccination. It is the only restaurant in San Francisco to have been closed over the vaccinate mandate, the health department said in a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: In a First, Surgeons Attached a Pig Kidney to a Human, and It Worked
description: A kidney grown in a genetically altered pig functions normally, scientists reported. The procedure may open the door to a renewable source of desperately needed organs.
content: Surgeons in New York have successfully attached a kidney grown in a genetically altered pig to a human patient and found that the organ worked normally, a scientific breakthrough that one day may yield a vast new supply of organs for severely ill patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: A Subway Rider Confronted Unmasked Police Officers. They Kicked Him Out.
description: Andrew Gilbert said he repeatedly asked two officers to wear masks in accordance with M.T.A. and Police Department policy. He was eventually pushed out of the station.
content: A New York City police officer grabs a male commuter by his jacket and pushes him through an emergency exit door at a subway station in Manhattan, video posted to social media shows. “You’re being disruptive,” the officer tells him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Brazil Senate’s Pandemic Panel, in Last-Minute Shift, Softened Criminal Recommendations on Bolsonaro
description: Senators on the 11-member panel had second thoughts about the provability of homicide and genocide charges. Instead, they accused the president of “crimes against humanity.”
content: BRASÍLIA, Brazil — On Tuesday night, a Brazilian congressional panel was hours away from revealing on national television its recommendation that President Jair Bolsonaro should face homicide and genocide charges for his mishandling of the pandemic, which has killed 600,000 Brazilians. Then a few senators had second thoughts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Jens Weidmann, the longtime German central bank chief, will step down.
description: A prominent critic of loose fiscal policies, his departure comes amid disagreements with the European Central Bank over its low-interest-rate policies.
content: Jens Weidmann, the head of Germany’s central bank for a decade and a close ally of Angela Merkel, plans to step down by year-end, amid disagreements with the European Central Bank’s low-interest-rate policies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Small Needles and Short Lines: Biden’s Plan to Vaccinate Young Children
description: White House officials, anticipating the approval of coronavirus shots for 5- to 11-year-olds within weeks, will rely on doctors, clinics and pharmacies instead of mass inoculation sites.
content: WASHINGTON — The campaign to vaccinate young children in the United States against the coronavirus will not look like the adult version. There will be no mass inoculation sites. Pediatricians will be enlisted to help work with parents. Even the vials — and the needles to administer doses — will be smaller.

content: Medical marijuana is now legal in more than half of the country. The cities of Denver, Seattle, Washington and Oakland, Calif., have also decriminalized psilocybin (the psychedelic element in “magic mushrooms”). Oregon went one step further, decriminalizing all drugs in small quantities, including heroin, cocaine and methamphetamine.

title: Joe Manchin Gonna Joe Manchin

content: The squabbling over the Build Back Better plan, the ambitious climate change and social spending package that the Democrats need to pass on a party-line vote, has been running hot, with progressives and moderates squaring off, especially in the Senate. On Wednesday, there were even rumblings that Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia, the chamber’s most conservative Democrat, had devised a plan to strong-arm his colleagues into giving him his way on the deal or else he’d take his toys and leave the party to become an independent. Mr. Manchin denied the report, which appeared in Mother Jones magazine, with salty language and informed reporters, “I have no control over the rumors.”

content: There’s no doubt that mixers — standing and hand-held — have made baking so much easier. But there’s an enticing ease to whipping up a dessert without having to get one out, and without having to wash it afterward. content: The varieties of awfulness are myriad, with people mistreating one another for any number of reasons, but in “The End of Bias,” Jessica Nordell guides us through bad behavior of one particular kind. content: LONDON — In her debut novel, “Black Mamba Boy,” Nadifa Mohamed wrote about her father’s odyssey from East Africa to Europe during the 1930s and ’40s. Her second, “Orchard of Lost Souls,” chronicles the lives of three women in Somalia on the cusp of civil war. But it was while writing her latest novel, “The Fortune Men,” Mohamed said, that things finally fell into place.

title: Stir-Frying Without a Wok
description: Genevieve Ko wrote about achieving wok hei in her recipe for stir-fried brussels sprouts.
content: Good morning. I loved this column Genevieve Ko wrote for the newspaper that we sent to the plant yesterday, printed overnight, stuffed into blue bags and hurled in the direction of our home-delivery subscribers’ front doors this morning. It’s about how she’s keeping the culinary traditions of her immigrant parents alive, adapting Western kitchen equipment to the Cantonese recipes she grew up with and achieving the smoky deliciousness known as wok hei, or “breath of the wok,” using a skillet, oil, water and a lid.
